title: A Christmas Carol and Project Gutenberg

full_content:
# A Christmas Carol and Project Gutenberg

The community centers around 'A Christmas Carol', a novella by Charles Dickens, originally published in 1915, and its subsequent release as a free eBook by Project Gutenberg. Key entities include the author, the original publisher, contributors to the eBook, and cities associated with its publication.

## Significance of 'A Christmas Carol'

'A Christmas Carol' is a seminal work in English literature, authored by Charles Dickens. The novella's themes of redemption and social responsibility resonate with readers and have made it a staple of Christmas literature. Its original publication in 1915 by J. B. Lippincott Company marked the beginning of its journey as a classic, and it has since been adapted into numerous films, plays, and other media. The novella's enduring popularity demonstrates its cultural impact and relevance over time. [Data: Entities (3, 1); Relationships (1)]

## Role of J. B. Lippincott Company

J. B. Lippincott Company was the original publisher of 'A Christmas Carol' in 1915, which established the novella's place in literary history. As the first publisher, it played a crucial role in introducing Dickens's work to the public. The company's legacy continues to be associated with the novella, highlighting the importance of publishing in the dissemination of literary works. [Data: Entities (5); Relationships (1)]

## Project Gutenberg's contribution

Project Gutenberg's release of 'A Christmas Carol' as a free eBook on December 24, 2007, has made the novella accessible to a global audience. This initiative aligns with Project Gutenberg's mission to promote the creation and distribution of eBooks, thereby enhancing the availability of classic literature. The free distribution under the Project Gutenberg License encourages educational use and broadens the readership of Dickens's work. [Data: Entities (4); Claims (25)]

## Contributors to the eBook

Several contributors, including Suzanne Shell, Janet Blenkinship, and the Online Distributed Proofreading Team, played vital roles in producing the Project Gutenberg eBook version of 'A Christmas Carol'. Their collaborative efforts ensure that the eBook is accurately presented and accessible, reflecting the importance of teamwork in literary projects. Each contributor's work contributes to the preservation and dissemination of classic literature. [Data: Entities (7, 8, 9); Relationships (5, 6, 7)]

## Illustration by Arthur Rackham

Arthur Rackham's illustrations for 'A Christmas Carol' enhance the visual appeal of the novella and contribute to its artistic legacy. His work helps to bring Dickens's characters and scenes to life, enriching the reader's experience. The illustrations are particularly significant in editions of the novella that reference them, showcasing the interplay between text and visual art in literature. [Data: Entities (2); Relationships (2)]

## Publication cities: Philadelphia and New York

'A Christmas Carol' was originally published in two significant cities: Philadelphia and New York. These locations are integral to the novella's publication history and reflect the literary culture of the early 20th century. The association with these cities adds to the novella's historical context and significance in American literature. [Data: Entities (10, 6); Relationships (8, 9)]
